snippet: Parents who can afford to shop only at mass-market retailers won’t find the kinds of playthings, like games of logic or sequence, that can help their children advance.
abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column argues that children's toys have become another manifestation of class differences, as educational toys are marketed to parents in wealthy neighborhoods while big box toy store offerings reign elsewhere; considers implications of commercial system in which least-privileged children are choked off from recreations most explicitly geared toward creativity and achievement.
lead_paragraph: Parents who can afford to shop only at mass-market retailers won’t find the kinds of playthings, like games of logic or sequence, that can help their children advance.

headline.print_headline: The Great Divide, Now in the Toy Aisle
